ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: An intimate discussion-based seminar guided by weekly readings and guided questions.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I learned a lot about (a certain branch) of literature written in French.

I think my writing improved a lot, and I began formulating original ideas in French, instead of translating from English. Obviously, that's a more personal answer, but the readings and discussions in this class are bound to improve your level of thinking/writing in French in one way or another.

Finally, I had to opportunity to consider a wide range of perspectives on femininity, feminism, religion, family, etc.

I improved greatly in my confidence when speaking and writing. I also took on readings that I would never have considered before which was great. The course exposed me to all different kinds of literary forms from various francophone regions. I have a greater understanding of the different forms of self-narratives and how they relate to female empowerment and independence.
I would say that my French literacy improved considerably, and I also learned a lot about French culture and societal dynamics.
My French reading comprehension, vocabulary, and writing skills improved.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I think the course's small size and level of interaction were the major plus. As the semester went on, the five of us became a lot more comfortable together, and I think the discussions improved accordingly.

Mme. Sanjabi is the kind of professor who I'd describe as "casually brilliant." She says things like they're no big deal, and then a few seconds later you realize that she's just expressed a really complicated idea that you had never even considered.

I did feel like the workload was very manageable throughout the semester and suddenly became very high during the last week, when we had to turn in an essay and prepare a final presentation. However, Mme. Sanjabi was very flexible and understanding of our concerns - more so, in fact, than any other professor I had this semester.

The course is rigorous but the work is not too challenging and it is manageable. However, I constantly felt behind the other students and there wasn't time to catch up or work towards understanding due to the pace of the course. There isn't much tutorial support or a writing tutor so it is very self-selective. Some of the readings are also uncommon so it can start to feel isolated when there aren't many people or sources who understand and can support you. Madam Sanjabi did do a great job at doing the best she can to provide context, history, and analysis on each reading. We also spent time examining each other to also help investigate their writing.
I just wish we had more students in the class - loved the ones we had, but we were a small group

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I don't have too much to say here: the class was basically a conversation over Zoom, and there weren't too many crazy tech innovations (nor did I feel that the class NEEDED any crazy tech innovations).

I think that the course allowed for the most virtual engagement possible. The teacher was incredibly flexible when it came to rescheduling class or giving extensions on homework. I found myself engaged throughout the entire class period as it was necessary to maintain conversations. I don't have any suggestions for improvement.
I think that our frequent and vibrant discussions over Zoom made this class feel as close to an in-person class as possible

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you love speaking, reading, and writing in French and considering a wide variety of ideas/perspectives for their own sake. No, if you prefer larger classes, or if you're just trying to get a language requirement filled.

I think that this class is rigorous and requires a previous understanding of french and literary analysis. It is challenging but incredibly fascinating and you will find yourself wanting to engage with the material even if you don't fully understand it. This is a first-year seminar which means you will only get the chance to take it as a first-year and you should. The class truly is not about getting a good grade or getting a language requirement it is about learning and expanding your mind. Very interesting I do recommend.
Yes! This was a very interesting course and a really good introduction to French literature and culture.
Yes, to any French student who enjoys reading
